reviewText:
Office Battle is a top down action game, set in an office where you play as one of the many workers who have just been told they are being made redundant. The game was released in December 2015, being developed by Black Lime Studio, who has previously had some not so popular releases on Steam.

The game play is a very simple idea. You are in control of one worker and your boss has come up with a great idea to let everyone fight for their jobs. You pick up the nearest weapon in the office, don on your keyboard as a shield and of course, reach for the cardboard box in the corner as you step out into the hall ready for battle with your co-workers. You are rewarded with experience and gold for taking down your foes, as well as completing the stage. There are a couple of different stage modes you can take part in, these are a last man standing mode, a domination mode, and a survival mode.  The game’s talent spending system is really easy to get your head around too, only two talent trees to learn, meaning you can pick and choose which ability to aid you in your current situation. The in game shop is where you will spend a lot of your time, as you try and buy the most recent new weapon or piece of armour to take into fight.

Visually, Office Battle is again, very simple. No mind blowingly good graphics here, just your generic looking cartoony style game. It does look better than your standard game though, with it on part with I would say a few Sims games. The office furniture is well modelled as well as quite a few unique character models throughout.  The animation is where this game is let down slightly; the game’s hitboxes are a little bit off making positioning a little difficult at times. The UI in game is clean and easy to understand too.  A really cool addition to this game, is the sound track, some very high tempo upbeat club mix soundtrack is in the background as you run around the halls of the office. Whilst it doesn’t quite make sense totally, it does fit the game play really well as it keeps you on your toes without you realizing it.

The usual levels offer no real difficulty to get through, where Office Battle really shows some challenge, is on the bosses. The first boss is a real challenge and forced me to replay the last level probably about 10 times in order for me to grind up enough levels and gold in order to just overpower him. A mistake I made was making my character too defensibly minded; I think it would have proved a better move to go offensive right from the start with the talent points. Whilst I am not a huge fan of a game forcing you to replay previously completed content, I don’t feel so bad doing it here; I think it’s because the stages last no longer than 2 and a half minutes usually and the rewards are often worth the time it takes anyway.

There is a substantial amount of content on offer in Office Battle; I have been playing for almost two hours now and I am only about 1/3 of the way through the main game. There is a free roam style mode but this offers no real benefit other than “just for fun” as you don’t get any experience or rewards out of it. Whether there is much replay ability, remains to be seen. If things carry on the way they are so far, I don’t see there being any reason to play through this game more than once unfortunately.

Technically, there are a few issues here and there. Firstly the game will run at 1080p as a maximum. Whilst that is the PC standard at the moment, a 1440p or 4k option would of even better especially since they are becoming more popular formats.  Secondly, the game claims to have partial controller support, sadly neither my Xbox nor Steam controller worked at all. The keyboard controls are really weird too; you control your character with the directional arrow keys and you punch/kick with WASD. Personally this is completely wrong, it would be much better to control the character with WASD and attack with the mouse. It makes navigating the character very tricky at times and I got stuck behind office furniture more times than I would like to admit due to the controller problems.

Despite the technical gripes I had with the game, I can’t really complain too much since it is priced ridiculously low at only 79p. If you want an evening’s worth of fun for less than a pound, then Office Battle will certainly do that.  Apart from fixing the controls, the only thing that stops this game being a hidden gem, is some form of local multiplayer option.

Tom's Score Card
1) Stay away
2) Not Recommended
3) Only recommended when on sale
4) Recommended
5) Highly recommended
6) This is a must play

If you found this review helpful, please give it a thumbs up. If you would also like to follow my reviews more easily, be sure to join my group by clicking here.

You may also be interested in checking out a PC gaming podcast, be sure to head here.

reviewText:
Your boss tells all the people in the office to fight. And what do you do? Pick up the nearest blunt weapon (yesterday's newspaper maybe), put a cardboard box on your head, and let's go beat everybody!

Office Battle offers, for less than a single euro, an ultimate experience of how to get bored in few minutes by doing something repeatedly that doesn't give you any motivation to progress further. There are few modes, passive skill trees, inventory system but... all you'll be doing is mashing the punch, uppercut and kick keys until everybody in the office lies down on the floor. Honestly, I don't get it how it gets so many positive reviews.

There's nothing else for you there, you can just try to get the best scores for the leaderboards - if you are the score guy"
date: you might like to lose your mind for a few minutes in Office Battle regularly. For others
recommended: it's not worth the low price - you might ignore a lost euro
hoursPlayed: but you won't get the spent minutes back.\n\nIt surprises me that Office Battle is made exclusively for PC players
voteText:
I'd expect getting similar game more popular on mobile platforms like Android and iOS.

reviewText:
Everyone wishes to rampage across the office and murder their coworkers with keyboards, mugs and rolled up newspapers. It is the urban dream and this game tries to capture such a wonderful fantasy....

There are various modes in this game which generally consist of the generic capture the safe points, survive for XYZ amount of seconds and kill XYZ amount of enemies. Not that original if you ask me.

The weapons and armour are original to this game (cardoard box helmet YES PLEASE) although there is a small selection with the majority of them being unlocked later in the game. The more enemies you kill, the more experience to new levels you gain, and the more money you pick up.

HOWEVER  - - - This game is boring as sin. It is interesting for the first few minutes until you realise everything is the same. The same enemies the same weapons the same layout. Some games benefit from repetition like Diablo or Minecraft. This game really really doesnt. There are limited rewards for your hard work, and most of the better content is locked behind several hours of mundane play.

Buy it on sale, but its a dissapointing game for such a good premise.

reviewText:
7.5/10 - Strangely Addicting; Way worth the Full Price

I had to do a double check after wasting several hours on this one. It has the same addictive quality you find in Clicker Hero’s and Timberman. This time the game unfolds as an office beat em' up! Last Man/Woman standing gets to keep their jobs! You’ll use trashcans for helmets, rulers for swords and the list goes on! Maps and overall game is pretty simple but the combat and diversity of objectives keep me coming back for more.

There are over 60 challenging levels with several different modes including last man standing, survival, bosses and more! Each level alternates missions so things stay fresh and exciting; this is a totally achievable 100% at around 15 hours? It requires A LOT of level farming/grinding but totally doable; I typically watch something on TV in conjunction to playing this with no sound. I won't 100% this, after completing the game I still have hours and hours left. It's fun... but not that fun.

Well worth the $1! At least 7-10 hours of Campaign and Leveling!

reviewText:
Introduction
Office Battle is an Indie Beat ‘em up, in which the goal is to defeat all coworkers in order to keep your Job.
The player can kick and punch with both arms and also use weapons and armor to achieve this goal. Unfortunately these are the only attack options which are presented. There are two kinds of items which can be found: protective items like shields and helmets and melee weapons. All of them are frequently dropped by enemies or can alternatively be bought at the store between levels using in-game currency. Although there is a large amount of different items, they are all functionally the same and only differ in the amount in which they boost the offensive or defensive stat. Additionally the skill tree also only offers passive power ups, the result of which is, that the the first level and all of the following are mechanically the same with only a minor sense of progression.

Additionally to the main campaign there is a level editor mode which is usable to create an office using all assets, which are in-game. Walls and floors have to be arranged around a grid, while items such as chairs, tables or decorations can be placed completely freely.
While there is a way to play in the created levels there is no way to share them online and playing them is ultimately inconsequently since no experience or items can be earned while fighting in them.

There are five game modes: Survival, Office Capture, Last Man Standing and Big B as well as Empty Office. The last of which never appears during the main campaign and only exists to showcase own created levels.
Survival, Office Capture and Last Man Standing are all pretty straightforward in that the player has to fight several waves of enemies which spawn indefinitely until the matching conditions are met, which are passing of time limit, visiting certain points in the level for a certain amount of time and defeating a certain amount of enemies respectively. The last mode, Big B, is a Boss Mode, where one enemy is replaced by a slower, albeit much stronger foe. While this seems like a decent amount of variety at first the game modes are all pretty similar, since all of them involve defeating enemies in the same way and only one of the game modes actually differs depending on the layout of the level.

As mentioned previously,  there is little variety in the gameplay. While there are critical hits and it is possible to stun enemies when attacking with precise timing, there is little strategy involved, since there is no real way to start combos and all the attacks seem to be equally fast and powerful.
There is also no multiplayer mode, with the only online feature being a global leaderboard.

Another problem involving the gameplay is the frequency in which the player can get stuck on walls. While this isn’t a problem most of the time, it becomes one upon entering a doorway, which are sprinkled through the level design moderately common. This is especially hard if there is an assault of several enemies at the same time, so these make for effective traps and have to be watched out for.

The graphics are colorful and fitting, but nothing spectacular. They do the job, while not being too straining on the computer, assuring smooth gameplay.
The sound effects and music are fitting, but nothing unique or out of the ordinary.

Pros
+ Easy to learn gameplay
+ Good customization
+ Global leaderboard

Cons
- Repetitive
- Easy to get stuck on walls
- Limited online features
- Minor grammatical errors in item and skill descriptions

Conclusion
While the game can become repetitive after a while, due to lack of variety it still achieves to be what it aspires: A fun little brawler in an unusual setting. Which can be played from time to time. While not doing anything anything other than the minimum it is build competently and can provide at least some enjoyment for only a small asking price.

Rating: 6/10

This review was submitted for Elite Giveaways, check us out for more reviews ranging from Indie games to AAA games to F2P games.

reviewText:
This is a very good example of a game with a good fun-price balance. For a dollar we have a fun little game that we can play sometimes.

This is a beat'em up with a pretty good controlls, good music and nice graphics for a Unity game. What's weak is the fact that the game gets repetitive fast. Boss levels are insane - your character is low-levelled when you get around to level 10 boss. You get beaten fast and need to repeat previous levels in order to level up your character. That's tedious.

Pros:
- really nice music
- decent graphics
- we get a decent amount of fun for a dollar
- really original items - weapons, shields and helmets made from everyday use items
- we have a levelling system in this game
- controlls are good, especially on a gamepad

Cons:
- gets repetitive in about half an hour
- levelling pace is somewhat mediocre at first and gets slower with each level
- items break really fast, boosting skills responsible for item durability helps little
- boss levels are absurdly hard
- no point in playing this game for too long - there is not really much to unlock
- high end items are not really that powerful
- items cost much, you gain little coins with every level

Few words about DLC - I bought this Brutal Mode DLC and that was a waste of 0,45E. It adds blood effects and some SFX like big smoke explosion when you score a critical hit. This should be included as an option into the base game, not as a DLC. It's as if you played Baldurs Gate 2 enhanced and fireball spell would be cut from base game and added as a DLC for 1$. That's a cheap sales philosophy.

To summarize - base game is fun to play, don't buy the dlc.

reviewText:
While the concept is very interesting and somewhat original , I cannot recommend this game.

The whole game is a repetition of button mashing with three different attacks. You cannot defend enemy attacks. You cannot dodge enemy attacks. You cannot counter enemy attacks.

Game dynamic: Stand still or go to a given spot ( the directional doesnt really matter as you will get hit anyway and cannot interact with the enviroment ),  smash the buttons to attack as the enemies runs towards you.  Pick a fewl coins from dead enemies and when you eventually die ( and you will! ) you can shop for weapons or items and start all over again.

While there are different  missions "
date: they are all loose with no game story at all and the dynamic is the same ( in one of them you need to defend a spot
recommended: in another you need to beat you boss
hoursPlayed: but gameplay never changes )\n\nToo bad as with a few adjustments this game could have been awesome. The basic elements are there - controls respond well
voteText: decent graphics
helpfulPercent: rich enviroment ( I still cannot believe there is ZERO interaction with the enviroment - no hidding
votesHelpful: no pushing furniture onto your enemies
votesTotal: no picking up stuff from the desks
votesFunny: etc... )\n\nI recommend avoiding this even at an extremely low price. And I cant help but wonder how this game got so many good reviews."

reviewText: I recommend Office Battle for it's uniqueness. I have not come accross another game on steam with this sort of style. The achievements possible in this game are not too difficult to achieve but will require grinding but not to the extent where you dislike the game itself. You are able to create your own office however you like as well as play a never ending match in your own office. The campaign isn't too difficult and leveling up your skills is not difficult at all. You are able to gain money just by replaying old missions and gain even more exp from the same one. The equipment available isn't large but is big enough for this game. I'd give this game about 8.1/10 rating overall.

Your boss, named Big B" (what's in a name?) organizes a (fighting) competition in which the winners get to keep their jobs. From time to time

reviewText: This is neither a fighting game nor a beat 'em up (in the vein of, say, Streets of Rage). It's a casual game through and through. There are three action buttons (left/right hook and kick) and the gameplay consists of finding a defensible bottleneck, turning to face incoming enemies and literally mashing those three buttons as quickly as possible. That's it. There are no special moves derived from special inputs. There are just under 60 levels of this and every tenth is a boss. All of it is extremely repetitive - the offices, the boss, everything.\n\nSo why the thumbs up? Because I enjoyed it quite a lot for some reason. No, I don't entirely understand why, but I had fun. The production values deserve mention as they are definitely above average for a title of this sort. Visuals, audio (all aspects: music, SFX, voice acting), interface/menus, performance... All of it is polished to a surprising degree, considering how shallow the game itself is. It's a stupid game, but pleasantly stupid.

reviewText: For what it costs, the core game isn't bad. I've actually paid far more for action games with a similar concept that have far less than what this title offers. It's up there with games I can throw on, turn my brain off to, and just senselessly beat the ever-lovin' ♥♥♥♥ out of coworkers in with my favorite death metal album blaring in the background through an alternate player (though the game's score is pretty catchy as well). Essentially it's a beat 'em up with RPG elements and additional game modes in the campaign that keep the gameplay fresh.\n\nThe Brutal Mode DLC, however? Meh. Doesn't seem to offer anything more than random blood stains on the ground. THAT I regret buying, but the main game is worth it for a buck (US currency).

reviewText: The boss, or Big B" is firing people. Fight to hold your place in the office. I'd say this is a top down puncher/brawler. As you kill your office mates
date: you can level up. Every level allows you to put points in different skills. You can collect and equip power ups like rulers for smaking people
recommended: and keyboards to use as a shield.\n\nThere are three 2 types of game when you play the campaign
hoursPlayed:
hold the office and survival. Hold the office involves standing in a particular spot long enough to capture the area. Survival is self explanatory.

Controls are very good. After a while the combat becomes a bit bland. I'd say that this is the sort of game that is good in small doeses.

Worth getting on a sale or paying full price for. It's cheap and fun."

Go to Store (Featured), Click on Games, Narrow by Feature (Steam Trading Cards), Relevance (Lowest Price).

Add them to your Wishlist, games that are a dollar can go on sale and you may be able to purchase for cheap!
A game at .50 may give you that value back in trading cards.
Search and Install Idle Master" which will run your games even without the game being installed.

reviewText:
Greetings fellow gamers! This is Gamer Guy (In a Suit) from the Echo Army YouTube channel! Today I am bringing you a review of the Indie Action game Office Battle. Office Battle was brought to us on Steam on December 2, 2015 by Publisher/Developer Black Lime Studios.

(NOTE: This game was reviewed using a key from my own Steam library and was NOT provided by the Developer/Publisher)

Video Review:

https://youtu.be/YrhjJk5uVag

The Too Long
recommended: you can do worse. Good way to blow off steam. Controls can be wonky
hoursPlayed:
though.
2.5/5 cause it's a buck.

The "Meat & Potatoes" Review:

Well
voteText: this is one of the better kinds of things you can find on Steam for a buck these days. That's for sure. Let's give you some pluses to look forward to. First off
helpfulPercent: this is a fun way to blow off some steam. Just go into an office and pound some co-workers. Add in the "Brutal" DLC (also a buck) and the extra-gory blood really can be a good release. You meander through the levels and meet the goal to move on. Usually the goal is something like "Survive the wave of Co-workers"
votesHelpful: etc. It's a Unity game. The graphics are decent as is the sound. The controls actually hold this one back a touch
votesTotal: as they get a little wonky at times. I had to mark it down .5 for that. It did not play any better with a controller
votesFunny: although if you take your time to re-map the entire control setup
column17: it is worth it and can be a fun way to let loose after a trying day. There are definitely MUCH worse games on Steam right now. This one
column18: while just slightly above average right now
column19:
is a fun concept and is absolutely worth your dollar (or two if you go "Brutal") 2.5/5. Not too shabby.

Happy Gaming!!!
"

reviewText:
This is a terrible game, and let me tell you why.

Control Issues
I got into the game and I expected it to use WASD and mouse. I was wrong. It uses the arrow keys (which I wasn't upset about) and Q, W, and E. I was upset, because I went into the game and I had no idea what I was doing.

Graphics
The graphics are REALLY bad. Lemme show you a screenshow of what you are greeted with when you enter the game. http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=567302128 Yeah. It's bad.

Items
They are all the same.

TL;DR Version.
It's a bad game and not worth the 1 dollar out of your pocket.
